P.title: Will the United Nations announce a new global initiative to combat climate change by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United Nations has officially announced a new global initiative specifically aimed at combating climate change. The initiative must represent a significant commitment beyond existing programs and must be aimed at reducing global carbon emissions, promoting renewable energy, or enhancing climate resilience. The announcement must come from an official UN source or be confirmed by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event of an announcement close to the resolution date, the initiative must be clearly defined and have a planned implementation timeline. Initiatives that are purely exploratory, lack specific goals, or are limited to funding research without actionable plans do not meet the criteria for resolution.

Q_given_P.title: Given the United Nations announces a new global initiative to combat climate change by 2025, will the Bureau of Labor Statistics introduce a new category for AI and robotics-related jobs by 2025?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United Nations has officially announced a new global initiative specifically aimed at combating climate change. The initiative must represent a significant commitment beyond existing programs and must be aimed at reducing global carbon emissions, promoting renewable energy, or enhancing climate resilience. The announcement must come from an official UN source or be confirmed by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event of an announcement close to the resolution date, the initiative must be clearly defined and have a planned implementation timeline. Initiatives that are purely exploratory, lack specific goals, or are limited to funding research without actionable plans do not meet the criteria for resolution.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) has officially introduced a new category specifically for AI and robotics-related jobs within its employment classifications. The introduction of such a category must be documented in an official BLS publication or press release. In the absence of a direct announcement, credible reports from at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence. The new category must distinctly cover jobs primarily focused on the development, maintenance, or operation of AI and robotics technologies, excluding broader categories that may incidentally include these roles.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Given both a new UN global climate initiative and a new BLS category for AI and robotics jobs by 2025, will a UN member introduce a resolution to regulate AI globally by 2025?
R_given_P_and_Q.body:
Suppose the following is true: By December 31, 2025, (a) the United Nations has officially announced a new global initiative specifically aimed at combating climate change, and (b) the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) has officially introduced a new category specifically for AI and robotics-related jobs within its employment classifications. Then, will a member country of the United Nations officially introduce a resolution aimed at regulating artificial intelligence (AI) on a global scale by December 31, 2025?

Resolution criteria for the condition: 
(a) The UN initiative must represent a significant commitment beyond existing programs and must be aimed at reducing global carbon emissions, promoting renewable energy, or enhancing climate resilience. The announcement must come from an official UN source or be confirmed by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the event of an announcement close to the resolution date, the initiative must be clearly defined and have a planned implementation timeline. Initiatives that are purely exploratory, lack specific goals, or are limited to funding research without actionable plans do not meet the criteria for resolution.
(b) The introduction of the new BLS category must be documented in an official BLS publication or press release. In the absence of a direct announcement, credible reports from at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence. The new category must distinctly cover jobs primarily focused on the development, maintenance, or operation of AI and robotics technologies, excluding broader categories that may incidentally include these roles.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: The resolution must seek to establish guidelines, standards, or laws applicable to the development, deployment, or use of AI technologies across multiple countries. The introduction of such a resolution must be confirmed by an official UN document or announcement. In the absence of direct UN confirmation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence. The resolution must be formally presented in a UN session or committee for discussion or voting. Preliminary discussions, proposals, or mentions that do not lead to a formal introduction do not count towards this question's resolution.

reasons: The introduction of a new global initiative to combat climate change by the United Nations could influence global economic and technological trends, which might indirectly affect the job market, including the creation of new job categories by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

A resolution to regulate artificial intelligence globally could be part of broader efforts to address technological impacts on climate change, making the combination of these questions relevant.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant as they all pertain to global policy changes and technological advancements that could be interconnected.

P.title: Will a landmark legal case involving quantum mechanics principles emerge before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a legal case is recognized as a landmark case involving the principles of quantum mechanics. A "landmark case" is defined as a case that sets a precedent, significantly influences the law, legal processes, or government policy, and is widely recognized within the legal community and by reputable news sources. The case must explicitly involve the principles of quantum mechanics as a central issue. Recognition must come from official legal documentation or announcements, or in the absence of such, by coverage in at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). In the event of multiple qualifying cases, the first to be officially recognized as meeting these criteria will determine the resolution. This question resolves as YES upon such recognition, otherwise, it resolves as NO.

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on a landmark legal case involving quantum mechanics principles emerging before 2030, will Japan lead the development of a groundbreaking computing technology by 2030?

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Given a landmark legal case involving quantum mechanics principles emerges and Japan leads the development of a groundbreaking computing technology by 2030, will the integration of AI into financial systems cause the value of the US dollar to fluctuate significantly by 2030?
R_given_P_and_Q.body:
Suppose the following is true: By January 1, 2030, both (a) a legal case is recognized as a landmark case involving the principles of quantum mechanics, and (b) Japan is recognized as the leading country in the development of a groundbreaking computing technology. The landmark case must set a precedent, significantly influence the law, legal processes, or government policy, and be widely recognized within the legal community and by reputable news sources. The case must explicitly involve the principles of quantum mechanics as a central issue. Recognition must come from official legal documentation or announcements, or in the absence of such, by coverage in at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). In the event of multiple qualifying cases, the first to be officially recognized as meeting these criteria will determine the resolution. Japan's leadership in groundbreaking computing technology must be confirmed through official announcements from a leading Japanese research institution or technology company, coverage by at least three reputable global news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, Reuters), or recognition by a reputable international technology or scientific organization. In the case of collaborative international projects where Japan plays a leading but not exclusive role, the question will resolve as Yes only if Japan's contribution is widely recognized as pivotal and transformative. Technologies that are only incremental improvements or do not have a clear path to commercialization or practical application by 2030 do not meet the criteria for this question.

Then, will the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into financial systems cause the value of the US dollar to fluctuate significantly by December 31, 2030? Significant fluctuation is defined as a change of more than 10% in the value of the US dollar against a basket of major currencies (Euro, Japanese Yen, British Pound, Canadian Dollar, Swiss Franc, and Australian Dollar) within a single calendar year, as reported by the Federal Reserve. The fluctuation must be directly attributed to the integration of AI into financial systems, as confirmed by statements from the Federal Reserve or credible financial analysis from at least three major financial news organizations (Bloomberg, Financial Times, Reuters). In the absence of direct attribution, a consensus among economic experts in peer-reviewed journals or major financial conferences indicating AI's significant impact on the dollar's value will also be considered.

P_and_Q_and_R.title: Will both a landmark legal case involving quantum mechanics principles emerge, Japan lead the development of a groundbreaking computing technology, and the integration of AI into financial systems cause the value of the US dollar to fluctuate significantly by 2030?
P_and_Q_and_R.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if all of the following occur before January 1, 2030:

(a) A legal case is recognized as a landmark case involving the principles of quantum mechanics. A "landmark case" is defined as a case that sets a precedent, significantly influences the law, legal processes, or government policy, and is widely recognized within the legal community and by reputable news sources. The case must explicitly involve the principles of quantum mechanics as a central issue. Recognition must come from official legal documentation or announcements, or in the absence of such, by coverage in at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). In the event of multiple qualifying cases, the first to be officially recognized as meeting these criteria will determine the resolution.

(b) Japan is recognized as the leading country in the development of a groundbreaking computing technology. Groundbreaking computing technology is defined as a technology that represents a significant advancement over existing technologies in terms of performance, efficiency, or capability, and has the potential to transform the computing industry. The leadership in development must be confirmed through:
- Official announcements from a leading Japanese research institution or technology company;
- Coverage by at least three reputable global news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, Reuters);
- Recognition by a reputable international technology or scientific organization.

In the case of collaborative international projects where Japan plays a leading but not exclusive role, the question will resolve as Yes only if Japan's contribution is widely recognized as pivotal and transformative. Technologies that are only incremental improvements or do not have a clear path to commercialization or practical application by 2030 do not meet the criteria for this question.

(c) The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into financial systems has caused the value of the US dollar to fluctuate significantly. Significant fluctuation is defined as a change of more than 10% in the value of the US dollar against a basket of major currencies (Euro, Japanese Yen, British Pound, Canadian Dollar, Swiss Franc, and Australian Dollar) within a single calendar year, as reported by the Federal Reserve. The fluctuation must be directly attributed to the integration of AI into financial systems, as confirmed by statements from the Federal Reserve or credible financial analysis from at least three major financial news organizations (Bloomberg, Financial Times, Reuters). In the absence of direct attribution, a consensus among economic experts in peer-reviewed journals or major financial conferences indicating AI's significant impact on the dollar's value will also be considered.

This question resolves as YES only if all (a), (b), and (c) occur, otherwise, it resolves as NO.

P.title: Will the average global temperature increase by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels before 2050?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2050, the global average temperature is confirmed to have increased by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels (defined as the average global temperature from 1850-1900). The assessment must be based on the annual average global surface temperature data as reported by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) or another authoritative scientific body that is recognized by the scientific community. In the event that the IPCC or the designated authoritative body discontinues, merges, or is replaced, the most directly comparable successor organization will be used for the resolution. Should there be significant controversy or dispute within the scientific community regarding the accuracy or interpretation of the data, the question will resolve based on the consensus opinion of the scientific community as reflected in peer-reviewed scientific literature.

Q_given_P.title: Given a global temperature increase of more than 2 degrees Celsius before 2050, will the United States enter a recession before 2025?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, the United States officially enters a recession. A recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) of the U.S. Department of Commerce. The determination of a recession by the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER), which is considered the authoritative body on U.S. recessions, will also result in a Yes resolution. In the absence of an official declaration, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) confirming the recession will be sufficient for resolution. This question resolves as NO if these conditions are not met by the specified date.

Criterion for condition: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2050, the global average temperature is confirmed to have increased by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels (defined as the average global temperature from 1850-1900). The assessment must be based on the annual average global surface temperature data as reported by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) or another authoritative scientific body that is recognized by the scientific community. In the event that the IPCC or the designated authoritative body discontinues, merges, or is replaced, the most directly comparable successor organization will be used for the resolution. Should there be significant controversy or dispute within the scientific community regarding the accuracy or interpretation of the data, the question will resolve based on the consensus opinion of the scientific community as reflected in peer-reviewed scientific literature.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Given both a significant global temperature increase and a U.S. recession, will the Amazon rainforest's rate of deforestation decrease by 30% by 2025?
R_given_P_and_Q.body: Suppose the following is true: (a) before January 1, 2050, the global average temperature is confirmed to have increased by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels (defined as the average global temperature from 1850-1900). The assessment must be based on the annual average global surface temperature data as reported by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) or another authoritative scientific body that is recognized by the scientific community. In the event that the IPCC or the designated authoritative body discontinues, merges, or is replaced, the most directly comparable successor organization will be used for the resolution. Should there be significant controversy or dispute within the scientific community regarding the accuracy or interpretation of the data, the question will resolve based on the consensus opinion of the scientific community as reflected in peer-reviewed scientific literature. (b) before January 1, 2025, the United States officially enters a recession. A recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) of the U.S. Department of Commerce. The determination of a recession by the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER), which is considered the authoritative body on U.S. recessions, will also result in a Yes resolution. In the absence of an official declaration, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) confirming the recession will be sufficient for resolution. Then is the following true: By December 31, 2025, the rate of deforestation in the Amazon rainforest has decreased by at least 30% compared to the rate recorded in the year 2020? The assessment of the deforestation rate will be based on data provided by the National Institute for Space Research (INPE) of Brazil, or any other authoritative source recognized by the international scientific community. In the event that INPE or equivalent authoritative data is not available for 2025, this question will resolve using the most recent data available from these sources prior to 2025. For the purpose of this question, "deforestation" refers to the permanent removal of primary forest cover in the Amazon basin. Temporary changes in forest cover due to natural events (e.g., fires, floods) that are expected to recover naturally do not count towards the deforestation rate.

R.title: Will the Amazon rainforest's rate of deforestation decrease by 30% by 2025?
R.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the rate of deforestation in the Amazon rainforest has decreased by at least 30% compared to the rate recorded in the year 2020.
The assessment of the deforestation rate will be based on data provided by the National Institute for Space Research (INPE) of Brazil, or any other authoritative source recognized by the international scientific community.
In the event that INPE or equivalent authoritative data is not available for 2025, this question will resolve using the most recent data available from these sources prior to 2025.
For the purpose of this question, "deforestation" refers to the permanent removal of primary forest cover in the Amazon basin. Temporary changes in forest cover due to natural events (e.g., fires, floods) that are expected to recover naturally do not count towards the deforestation rate.

reasons: Climate change, as indicated by a significant increase in global temperatures, can have wide-ranging economic impacts, including the potential to trigger or exacerbate recessions. For instance, extreme weather events and long-term shifts in climate patterns can disrupt economic activities, reduce agricultural yields, and increase costs for businesses and governments, potentially leading to economic downturns.

The rate of deforestation in the Amazon rainforest is closely linked to global climate change. The Amazon acts as a significant carbon sink, and its deforestation contributes to higher levels of CO2 in the atmosphere, which in turn can accelerate global warming. Therefore, changes in deforestation rates can be both a cause and an effect of global temperature changes.

Economic conditions, such as a recession in the United States, can influence environmental policies and funding for conservation efforts. During economic downturns, there may be reduced funding for environmental protection, potentially leading to increased deforestation rates. Conversely, economic recovery and growth could lead to more resources being allocated to conservation efforts.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant and worth considering due to the interconnected nature of climate change, economic conditions, and environmental policies.

P.title: Will Japan lead the development of a groundbreaking computing technology by 2030?

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on Japan leading the development of a groundbreaking computing technology by 2030, will the US House of Representatives pass significant legislation to regulate artificial intelligence by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Japan is recognized as the leading country in the development of a groundbreaking computing technology. Groundbreaking computing technology is defined as a technology that represents a significant advancement over existing technologies in terms of performance, efficiency, or capability, and has the potential to transform the computing industry. The leadership in development must be confirmed through:
- Official announcements from a leading Japanese research institution or technology company;
- Coverage by at least three reputable global news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian, Reuters);
- Recognition by a reputable international technology or scientific organization.

In the case of collaborative international projects where Japan plays a leading but not exclusive role, the question will resolve as Yes only if Japan's contribution is widely recognized as pivotal and transformative. Technologies that are only incremental improvements or do not have a clear path to commercialization or practical application by 2030 do not meet the criteria for this question.

Given this, will the US House of Representatives pass significant legislation to regulate artificial intelligence by 2030? This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the US House of Representatives has passed legislation that significantly regulates artificial intelligence (AI) in any of the following areas: development, deployment, ethical use, privacy, security, or bias mitigation. 

Significant legislation is defined as a bill that introduces new regulations or substantially amends existing regulations on AI. The bill must be passed by the US House of Representatives and must not be solely symbolic; it must have practical implications for the regulation of AI. 

The passage of the legislation must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. 

In the event that multiple pieces of legislation are passed, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets the criteria outlined above.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Given Japan leads in groundbreaking computing technology development and the US House passes significant AI regulation by 2030, will the US Senate pass a significant bill related to international relations before 2025?

P.title: Will Tesla's advancements in battery technology significantly reduce carbon emissions worldwide by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Tesla's advancements in battery technology have led to a significant reduction in global carbon emissions. A "significant reduction" is defined as a decrease of at least 10% in global carbon emissions from 2020 levels, attributable directly to the adoption of Tesla's battery technology in electric vehicles, energy storage systems, or other applications. The assessment of Tesla's impact on carbon emissions will be based on data and analysis from authoritative sources such as the International Energy Agency (IEA), the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), or equivalent. Reports from at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the reduction and Tesla's contribution to it will also be considered sufficient for resolution. In the absence of clear data linking Tesla's battery technology to a global emissions reduction, the question will resolve as No.

Q_given_P.title: Given Tesla's advancements in battery technology significantly reduce carbon emissions worldwide by 2030, will a breakthrough in physics lead to a new form of clean energy by 2040?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: By December 31, 2030, Tesla's advancements in battery technology have led to a significant reduction in global carbon emissions. A "significant reduction" is defined as a decrease of at least 10% in global carbon emissions from 2020 levels, attributable directly to the adoption of Tesla's battery technology in electric vehicles, energy storage systems, or other applications. The assessment of Tesla's impact on carbon emissions will be based on data and analysis from authoritative sources such as the International Energy Agency (IEA), the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), or equivalent. Reports from at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the reduction and Tesla's contribution to it will also be considered sufficient for resolution. In the absence of clear data linking Tesla's battery technology to a global emissions reduction, the question will resolve as No.

Then, will a breakthrough in physics lead to a new form of clean energy by 2040? This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2040, a breakthrough in physics results in the development of a new form of clean energy that meets the following criteria:

- The energy source must be widely recognized as "clean," meaning it has minimal negative impact on the environment and emits low to no greenhouse gases during production or use.
- The breakthrough must be documented in at least one peer-reviewed scientific journal and recognized by a reputable scientific organization or consensus within the scientific community.
- The new energy source must be proven to be scalable for widespread use and demonstrate a significant advantage over existing clean energy sources in terms of efficiency, cost, or environmental impact.
- The development of the new energy source must be confirmed by an official announcement from a leading research institution or a major energy company.

In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The energy source must be operational, not merely theoretical or in a prototype phase, by the resolution date.

P.title: Will a major political figure propose a global summit on virology research funding before 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, a major political figure has officially proposed a global summit focused on virology research funding. A "major political figure" is defined as a current head of state, head of government, or a minister of health from any of the G20 nations. The proposal must be for a summit specifically aimed at discussing, planning, or increasing funding for virology research on a global scale. The proposal must be publicly documented through an official government press release, announcement, or in statements made during official government proceedings. In the absence of direct government documentation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. The summit does not need to take place by the resolution date; only the proposal is necessary for the question to resolve as Yes.

Q_given_P.title: Given a major political figure proposes a global summit on virology research funding before 2025, will the outcome of the 2020 US presidential election lead to major electoral reform in the United States by 2025?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: By December 31, 2024, a major political figure has officially proposed a global summit focused on virology research funding. Then, will the outcome of the 2020 US presidential election lead to major electoral reform in the United States by 2025? This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States has enacted significant electoral reform at the federal level in response to the outcome of the 2020 presidential election. Significant electoral reform is defined as any of the following:
- The adoption of a new voting system (e.g., ranked-choice voting, proportional representation) for federal elections;
- Major amendments to the Electoral College system, including but not limited to the abolition of the Electoral College or the implementation of a national popular vote compact;
- Substantial changes to voting rights legislation that materially affect the accessibility and fairness of federal elections, including but not limited to automatic voter registration, restoration of voting rights, or significant alterations to voter identification requirements.

The enactment of reform must be confirmed by official government documentation or announcements. In the absence of direct government confirmation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient.

In the event that multiple reforms are enacted, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one of the listed reforms meets the criteria above. Temporary measures or reforms only affecting state-level elections do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a major breakthrough in COVID-19 vaccine development be achieved through the use of artificial intelligence by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a major breakthrough in COVID-19 vaccine development is achieved with significant contribution from artificial intelligence (AI). A "major breakthrough" is defined as the development of a vaccine that demonstrates at least a 90% efficacy rate in preventing COVID-19 in Phase 3 clinical trials, as reported by a regulatory body such as the FDA, EMA, or WHO. The contribution of AI must be clearly documented and recognized in the research findings or publication, indicating that AI played a crucial role in the vaccine's development, such as through the identification of novel vaccine targets, acceleration of vaccine design, or optimization of vaccine formulations. The breakthrough must be confirmed by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or an official announcement from a leading health organization. In the absence of direct publication, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The vaccine must be approved for public use by the specified resolution date.

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on a major breakthrough in COVID-19 vaccine development being achieved through the use of artificial intelligence by 2025, will NATO implement AI-driven cybersecurity measures to protect its communications network by 2025?
Q_given_P.body:

The vaccine must be approved for public use by the specified resolution date.

2. By December 31, 2025, NATO has officially implemented artificial intelligence-driven cybersecurity measures to protect its communications networks. The implementation must be confirmed by an official NATO announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The measures must be operational, not in a trial phase, and must specifically aim to enhance the security of NATO's communications networks against cyber threats. The resolution will consider the deployment of AI technologies such as machine learning algorithms for threat detection, automated incident response systems, or AI-driven network monitoring and defense mechanisms. In the event of a partial implementation (e.g., limited to specific areas of the network), the question will resolve as Yes if the measures are intended for full network coverage.

If the first condition is not met, this question resolves as N/A.

P.title: Will the average global temperature increase by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels before 2050?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2050, the global average temperature is confirmed to have increased by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels (defined as the average global temperature from 1850-1900). The assessment must be based on the annual average global surface temperature data as reported by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) or another authoritative scientific body that is recognized by the scientific community. In the event that the IPCC or the designated authoritative body discontinues, merges, or is replaced, the most directly comparable successor organization will be used for the resolution. Should there be significant controversy or dispute within the scientific community regarding the accuracy or interpretation of the data, the question will resolve based on the consensus opinion of the scientific community as reflected in peer-reviewed scientific literature.

Q_given_P.title: Given the average global temperature increases by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels before 2050, will a new infectious disease emerge by 2030 that leads to a global pandemic with a mortality rate exceeding that of COVID-19?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2050, the global average temperature is confirmed to have increased by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels (defined as the average global temperature from 1850-1900). The assessment must be based on the annual average global surface temperature data as reported by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) or another authoritative scientific body that is recognized by the scientific community. In the event that the IPCC or the designated authoritative body discontinues, merges, or is replaced, the most directly comparable successor organization will be used for the resolution. Should there be significant controversy or dispute within the scientific community regarding the accuracy or interpretation of the data, the question will resolve based on the consensus opinion of the scientific community as reflected in peer-reviewed scientific literature.

This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges that leads to a global pandemic with a mortality rate exceeding that of COVID-19 as reported by the World Health Organization (WHO). The mortality rate is defined as the number of confirmed deaths divided by the number of confirmed cases. P.title: Will Ukraine's GDP per capita surpass that of Poland before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine's GDP per capita, as reported by the World Bank or another internationally recognized economic organization, surpasses that of Poland for any fiscal year. The GDP per capita should be calculated based on current US dollars for consistency. In the event that the World Bank or the designated authoritative source discontinues its reporting or significantly changes its methodology, an alternative reputable source will be used, following the same criteria for GDP per capita calculation. This question does not consider temporary fluctuations; the GDP per capita must be higher in one fiscal year compared to the previous year's report for Poland.

P.title: Will a new infectious disease be identified that significantly impacts global health by 2025?

Q_given_P.title: Given a new infectious disease significantly impacts global health by 2025, will a new AI-driven epidemiology tool predict the next global pandemic with over 90% accuracy before 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a new AI-driven epidemiology tool is developed and successfully predicts the next global pandemic with over 90% accuracy. The prediction must be specific to the pathogen type (e.g., virus, bacteria), its origin, and the timeframe of outbreak. The tool's prediction accuracy must be verified by a consensus of at least three leading health organizations (e.g., WHO, CDC, ECDC) or by publication in at least three peer-reviewed scientific journals. The tool must be publicly acknowledged by these organizations or publications as having met the 90% accuracy threshold in its prediction. In the event of multiple tools meeting these criteria, the resolution will be based on the first tool to be publicly acknowledged as meeting the accuracy threshold. Predictions made retrospectively, after the pandemic has begun, do not count towards this question's resolution.

Criterion for condition: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a new infectious disease is identified that significantly impacts global health. Significant impact is defined as:
- The disease causing at least 1,000 confirmed deaths worldwide;
- The disease leading to the declaration of a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) by the World Health Organization (WHO);
- The disease resulting in widespread travel restrictions or lockdowns in at least three countries.

The identification of the disease must be confirmed by the WHO or a similar authoritative health organization. In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient.

In the event that multiple diseases meet these criteria, the question will resolve as Yes if any one of them does so before the specified date. Diseases that are mutations or variants of previously identified diseases do not count unless they are classified as distinct new diseases by the WHO.

P.title: Will the United States enter a recession before 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, the United States officially enters a recession. A recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) of the U.S. Department of Commerce. The determination of a recession by the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER), which is considered the authoritative body on U.S. recessions, will also result in a Yes resolution. In the absence of an official declaration, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters) confirming the recession will be sufficient for resolution. This question resolves as NO if these conditions are not met by the specified date.

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on the United States entering a recession before 2025, will the value of Bitcoin exceed the US dollar in terms of global transaction volume by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the total global transaction volume of Bitcoin exceeds that of the US dollar. The transaction volume must be confirmed by data from authoritative financial tracking organizations or databases, such as the Bank for International Settlements (BIS), International Monetary Fund (IMF), or other recognized financial institutions. The comparison will consider the total volume of transactions processed within the calendar year 2030, including but not limited to retail transactions, cross-border transactions, and institutional transfers. In the event of discrepancies between sources, the majority consensus among these authoritative sources will be used to determine the outcome. Temporary spikes in transaction volume due to speculative trading or singular events will not be considered. The resolution will be based on the most reliable and comprehensive data available as of December 31, 2030.

Q_given_P.title: Conditional on a member of the United Nations introducing a resolution to regulate artificial intelligence globally by 2025, will Japan introduce a new constitution amendment related to digital privacy by 2025?
Q_given_P.body:

The introduction of such an amendment must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The amendment must be passed and incorporated into the Japanese Constitution, not merely proposed or under consideration. In the event of ambiguity regarding the amendment's focus on digital privacy, the question will resolve as No.

P.title: Will the United States announce a major scientific discovery in the field of natural sciences by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States officially announces a major scientific discovery in the field of natural sciences. A "major scientific discovery" is defined as a finding that significantly advances our understanding or application in one or more of the following areas: astronomy, biology, chemistry, earth science, or physics. The announcement must come from a recognized U.S. scientific organization or agency (e.g., NASA, National Science Foundation, U.S. Geological Survey) and be widely reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post, Nature, Science). In the absence of a single defining announcement, a consensus among the scientific community, as evidenced by publications in multiple peer-reviewed scientific journals or presentations at major scientific conferences, will also satisfy this criterion. The discovery must be new, not a development or extension of existing knowledge. In the event of multiple discoveries, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets these criteria.

Q_given_P.title: Given the United States announces a major scientific discovery in the field of natural sciences by 2025, will there be a significant discovery in robotics that contributes to the advancement of natural sciences by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: By December 31, 2025, the United States officially announces a major scientific discovery in the field of natural sciences. A "major scientific discovery" is defined as a finding that significantly advances our understanding or application in one or more of the following areas: astronomy, biology, chemistry, earth science, or physics. The announcement must come from a recognized U.S. scientific organization or agency (e.g., NASA, National Science Foundation, U.S. Geological Survey) and be widely reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post, Nature, Science). In the absence of a single defining announcement, a consensus among the scientific community, as evidenced by publications in multiple peer-reviewed scientific journals or presentations at major scientific conferences, will also satisfy this criterion. The discovery must be new, not a development or extension of existing knowledge. In the event of multiple discoveries, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets these criteria.

Then, will there be a significant discovery in robotics that contributes to the advancement of the natural sciences by 2030? A "significant discovery" is defined as a development in robotics technology or application that leads to a breakthrough in understanding, methodology, or application in any field of the natural sciences (e.g., biology, chemistry, physics, earth science). The discovery must be recognized as significant by the scientific community, evidenced by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal, citation in multiple subsequent research works, or acknowledgment by a reputable scientific organization. The advancement must be directly attributable to the robotics discovery and represent a clear departure from existing capabilities or knowledge. In the event of multiple discoveries, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets these criteria. Discoveries that are primarily advancements in computer science or engineering without direct application to the natural sciences do not count towards this question's resolution.

R_given_P_and_Q.title: Given major scientific discoveries in natural sciences and robotics, will a groundbreaking discovery related to dark matter be confirmed by 2030?
R_given_P_and_Q.body:
Suppose the following is true: (a) By December 31, 2025, the United States officially announces a major scientific discovery in the field of natural sciences. A "major scientific discovery" is defined as a finding that significantly advances our understanding or application in one or more of the following areas: astronomy, biology, chemistry, earth science, or physics. The announcement must come from a recognized U.S. scientific organization or agency (e.g., NASA, National Science Foundation, U.S. Geological Survey) and be widely reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post, Nature, Science). In the absence of a single defining announcement, a consensus among the scientific community, as evidenced by publications in multiple peer-reviewed scientific journals or presentations at major scientific conferences, will also satisfy this criterion. The discovery must be new, not a development or extension of existing knowledge. In the event of multiple discoveries, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets these criteria.

(b) By December 31, 2030, a significant discovery in robotics has been made that contributes to the advancement of the natural sciences. A "significant discovery" is defined as a development in robotics technology or application that leads to a breakthrough in understanding, methodology, or application in any field of the natural sciences (e.g., biology, chemistry, physics, earth science). The discovery must be recognized as significant by the scientific community, evidenced by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal, citation in multiple subsequent research works, or acknowledgment by a reputable scientific organization. The advancement must be directly attributable to the robotics discovery and represent a clear departure from existing capabilities or knowledge. In the event of multiple discoveries, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets these criteria. Discoveries that are primarily advancements in computer science or engineering without direct application to the natural sciences do not count towards this question's resolution.

Then is the following true: Before January 1, 2030, a groundbreaking discovery related to dark matter is confirmed by the scientific community. A "groundbreaking discovery" is defined as a discovery that significantly alters the current understanding of dark matter, its properties, or its role in the universe. This includes, but is not limited to, direct detection of dark matter particles, a conclusive demonstration of dark matter's interaction with ordinary matter beyond gravitational effects, or the discovery of phenomena that cannot be explained without invoking dark matter. The confirmation must come from findings published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal and recognized by a consensus of the scientific community, including major organizations such as the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN), the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), or the European Space Agency (ESA). In the absence of a consensus, the question will resolve as No. Edge cases will be considered on a case-by-case basis, with a preference for the most widely accepted scientific standards at the time of discovery.

P.title: Will the global average temperature rise by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the global average temperature has risen by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels (defined as the average global temperature from 1850-1900). The assessment must be based on the annual average global surface temperature data as reported by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) or another authoritative scientific body that provides a comprehensive analysis of global temperatures. In the event that the IPCC or equivalent body does not provide a clear statement or report by the resolution date, this question will resolve based on the consensus of reports from at least three major scientific organizations dedicated to climate science. Edge cases, such as significant revisions to historical temperature data or changes in the methodology for calculating global average temperatures, will be considered on a case-by-case basis, with a preference for the most widely accepted scientific standards at the time of resolution.

Q_given_P.title: Given the global average temperature rises by more than 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels by 2030, will a biotechnology breakthrough lead to a significant increase in global GDP by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a biotechnology breakthrough is directly linked to a significant increase in global GDP. A "significant increase" is defined as a rise in global GDP by at least 5% over a baseline year, adjusted for inflation, attributable to biotechnological advancements. The breakthrough must be widely recognized by the global economic and scientific communities, with confirmation from at least three of the following organizations or publications: The World Bank, International Monetary Fund (IMF), Nature Biotechnology, or Science. The increase in GDP must be reported by reputable global financial news sources, such as Bloomberg, Financial Times, or The Economist. In the event of multiple contributing factors to GDP growth, the biotechnology breakthrough must be identified as the primary driver. This question does not consider incremental improvements in existing biotechnologies but focuses on a novel breakthrough that marks a significant departure from current capabilities.

P.title: Will Google announce a significant breakthrough in natural sciences research by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Google (or any of its subsidiaries) officially announces a significant breakthrough in the field of natural sciences. A "significant breakthrough" is defined as a discovery or development that represents a major advancement in understanding or application in any of the natural sciences (including, but not limited to, biology, chemistry, physics, earth science, and astronomy). The announcement must be made through an official Google press release or a publication in a reputable scientific journal. The breakthrough must be recognized as significant by the scientific community, as evidenced by coverage in at least three major science news outlets (e.g., Scientific American, Nature News, Science Daily) or citations in peer-reviewed scientific journals. In the absence of widespread recognition, the question will resolve as No. The breakthrough must be new, not a continuation or incremental improvement of existing technologies or research.

Q_given_P.title: Given Google announces a significant breakthrough in natural sciences research by 2025, will a groundbreaking discovery related to dark matter be confirmed by the scientific community before 2030?

Then is the following true: Before January 1, 2030, a groundbreaking discovery related to dark matter is confirmed by the scientific community. A "groundbreaking discovery" is defined as a discovery that significantly alters the current understanding of dark matter, its properties, or its role in the universe. This includes, but is not limited to, direct detection of dark matter particles, a conclusive demonstration of dark matter's interaction with ordinary matter beyond gravitational effects, or the discovery of phenomena that cannot be explained without invoking dark matter. The confirmation must come from findings published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal and recognized by a consensus of the scientific community, including major organizations such as the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN), the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), or the European Space Agency (ESA). In the absence of a consensus, the question will resolve as No. Edge cases will be considered on a case-by-case basis, with a preference for the most widely accepted scientific standards at the time of discovery.

P.title: Will a new technology emerge by 2025 that significantly improves the detection and treatment of infectious diseases?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a new technology has emerged that significantly improves the detection and treatment of infectious diseases. Significant improvement is defined as:
- A reduction in detection time by at least 50% compared to the best available technology as of 2023.
- An increase in detection accuracy to at least 95%.
- A treatment method that reduces recovery time by at least 30% or increases the survival rate of severe cases by at least 20%, compared to the best available treatments as of 2023.
The emergence of such technology must be confirmed by the publication of results in at least two peer-reviewed scientific journals or an official announcement from a recognized health organization (e.g., WHO, CDC). Technologies that are only in the trial phase by the resolution date do not count. In the event of multiple technologies emerging, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets the above criteria.

Q_given_P.title: Given a new technology emerges by 2025 that significantly improves the detection and treatment of infectious diseases, will advancements in microbiology influence global health policies more than technology by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, advancements in microbiology have had a more significant influence on global health policies than technological advancements. Influence on global health policies is defined as the adoption of new or revised policies, guidelines, or recommendations by at least three of the following organizations: World Health Organization (WHO), Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), or similar national or international health bodies. The influence of microbiology advancements is measured by the direct citation of microbiological research or data in the formulation of these policies. Technological advancements include, but are not limited to, developments in medical devices, health information technologies, and biotechnology. The comparison between the influences of microbiology and technology will be assessed based on the number of policies influenced, the scope of the impact, and the depth of the changes implemented. In the event of ambiguity or lack of clear evidence, the question will resolve as No.

P.title: Will the value of investments in space exploration exceed the market capitalization of the US dollar by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the total value of investments in space exploration exceeds the market capitalization of the US dollar. The value of investments in space exploration includes all public and private funding, grants, and investments directed towards space exploration projects, including but not limited to satellite launches, manned missions, space station construction, and deep space probes. The market capitalization of the US dollar will be calculated based on the total amount of USD in circulation, including physical currency and digital forms, as reported by the United States Federal Reserve. Resolution will be based on data and reports from authoritative financial and space exploration entities, such as the United States Federal Reserve, NASA, ESA, SpaceX, and other recognized organizations in the field. In the event of conflicting reports, a consensus from at least three reputable financial or space exploration news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Financial Times, Space News) will be required for resolution.

P.title: Will the value of investments in space exploration exceed the market capitalization of the US dollar by 2030?

The market capitalization of the US dollar will be calculated based on the total amount of USD in circulation, including physical currency and digital forms, as reported by the United States Federal Reserve. Resolution will be based on data and reports from authoritative financial and space exploration entities, such as the United States Federal Reserve, NASA, ESA, SpaceX, and other recognized organizations in the field. Q.title: Will a new algorithm significantly improve the efficiency of medical data analysis by 2030?
Q.body: A "new algorithm" refers to a novel computational method or process, distinct from existing algorithms as of 2023, that enhances the efficiency of analyzing medical data. This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new algorithm is developed and publicly documented to significantly improve the efficiency of medical data analysis in terms of speed, accuracy, or cost reduction. The improvement must be quantifiable, with at least a 20% increase in efficiency compared to the best-known methods as of 2023. The algorithm must be validated through peer-reviewed research published in a reputable scientific or medical journal, or through widespread adoption by at least three leading healthcare institutions or companies. In the event of multiple algorithms being developed, the question will resolve as Yes if any one algorithm meets these criteria. The term "significant improvement" is defined as a measurable and substantial enhancement in processing speed, accuracy, or cost-effectiveness in the analysis of medical data, which could include patient records, imaging data, genetic information, or other relevant medical datasets.

P.title: Will the Bureau of Labor Statistics report a significant increase in green jobs in the US by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) in the United States reports a significant increase in green jobs compared to its last report prior to 2023. A "significant increase" is defined as a rise of at least 20% in the number of green jobs, as categorized and reported by the BLS. The BLS's definition of "green jobs" includes positions in businesses that produce goods or provide services that benefit the environment or conserve natural resources, as well as jobs in which workers' duties involve making their establishment's production processes more environmentally friendly or use fewer natural resources. In the absence of a direct report from the BLS, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the increase based on BLS data or analysis will be sufficient for resolution. This question will resolve as No if the criteria are not met by the specified date.

P.title: Will a member of the United Nations introduce a resolution to regulate artificial intelligence globally by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, any member country of the United Nations has officially introduced a resolution aimed at regulating artificial intelligence (AI) on a global scale. The resolution must seek to establish guidelines, standards, or laws applicable to the development, deployment, or use of AI technologies across multiple countries. The introduction of such a resolution must be confirmed by an official UN document or announcement. In the absence of direct UN confirmation, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient evidence. The resolution must be formally presented in a UN session or committee for discussion or voting. Preliminary discussions, proposals, or mentions that do not lead to a formal introduction do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a new technology emerge by 2025 that significantly improves the detection and treatment of infectious diseases?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a new technology has emerged that significantly improves the detection and treatment of infectious diseases. Significant improvement is defined as:
- A reduction in detection time by at least 50% compared to the best available technology as of 2023.
- An increase in detection accuracy to at least 95%.
- A treatment method that reduces recovery time by at least 30% or increases the survival rate of severe cases by at least 20%, compared to the best available treatments as of 2023.
The emergence of such technology must be confirmed by the publication of results in at least two peer-reviewed scientific journals or an official announcement from a recognized health organization (e.g., WHO, CDC). Technologies that are only in the trial phase by the resolution date do not count. In the event of multiple technologies emerging, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets the above criteria.

Temporary measures or proposals not enacted into law do not count towards this question's resolution.

A "significant discovery" is defined as a finding that leads to a notable advancement in the understanding, prevention, treatment, or eradication of a disease or health condition affecting a large portion of the global population. The announcement must be made through an official WHO press release or publication. In the absence of a direct announcement, confirmation by at least three reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) will be considered sufficient. Discoveries that are primarily technological or pharmaceutical in nature, without a clear and direct link to natural sciences, do not qualify. In the event of ambiguity, the consensus of the scientific community, as reflected in publications in peer-reviewed journals or statements by recognized health authorities, will be the deciding factor.

reasons: The emergence of a new technology that significantly improves the detection and treatment of infectious diseases could be influenced by policies implemented by the Democratic Party to boost technology startups. Increased funding, tax incentives, and regulatory changes could accelerate research and development in the health tech sector.

A significant natural sciences discovery announced by the WHO could be related to or even a result of the new technology that improves infectious disease detection and treatment. Such a discovery could also be facilitated by the Democratic Party's policies if they lead to increased collaboration and innovation in the health sector.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is relevant and worth considering, as there are plausible connections between the emergence of new health technologies, supportive policies for technology startups, and significant scientific discoveries in global health.

P.title: Will a breakthrough in aerospace engineering lead to a significant improvement in global pandemic response capabilities by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a breakthrough in aerospace engineering has led to a significant improvement in global pandemic response capabilities. A "significant improvement" is defined as a development that enables at least a 30% reduction in global pandemic response time or a 20% increase in the distribution efficiency of medical supplies, vaccines, or personnel compared to 2023 standards. The breakthrough must be in the field of aerospace engineering and directly contribute to the improvement of pandemic response capabilities. This includes, but is not limited to, innovations in aircraft design, logistics, and transportation technologies that enhance the speed, efficiency, or reach of pandemic response efforts. The improvement must be documented and recognized by at least one of the following: the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or a similar authoritative public health body. In the absence of official recognition, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. Temporary or experimental deployments do not count towards this question's resolution.

Q_given_P.title: Given a breakthrough in aerospace engineering leads to a significant improvement in global pandemic response capabilities by 2030, will a new vaccine for a major infectious disease be approved by the FDA by 2025?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: By December 31, 2030, a breakthrough in aerospace engineering has led to a significant improvement in global pandemic response capabilities. A "significant improvement" is defined as a development that enables at least a 30% reduction in global pandemic response time or a 20% increase in the distribution efficiency of medical supplies, vaccines, or personnel compared to 2023 standards. The breakthrough must be in the field of aerospace engineering and directly contribute to the improvement of pandemic response capabilities. This includes, but is not limited to, innovations in aircraft design, logistics, and transportation technologies that enhance the speed, efficiency, or reach of pandemic response efforts. In the absence of official recognition, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. Temporary or experimental deployments do not count towards this question's resolution.

Then, will a new vaccine for a major infectious disease be approved by the FDA by 2025? This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has officially approved a new vaccine for a major infectious disease. A "major infectious disease" is defined as a disease that has caused significant morbidity or mortality in the United States or globally within the last 10 years, as reported by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The approval must be for a vaccine that has not been previously available in the United States, and it must be intended for widespread use rather than limited to emergency authorization. The resolution will be based on official FDA announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The vaccine must be available for distribution within the United States to count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a biotechnology breakthrough lead to a significant increase in global GDP by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a biotechnology breakthrough is directly linked to a significant increase in global GDP. A "significant increase" is defined as a rise in global GDP by at least 5% over a baseline year, adjusted for inflation, attributable to biotechnological advancements. The breakthrough must be widely recognized by the global economic and scientific communities, with confirmation from at least three of the following organizations or publications: The World Bank, International Monetary Fund (IMF), Nature Biotechnology, or Science. The increase in GDP must be reported by reputable global financial news sources, such as Bloomberg, Financial Times, or The Economist. In the event of multiple contributing factors to GDP growth, the biotechnology breakthrough must be identified as the primary driver. This question does not consider incremental improvements in existing biotechnologies but focuses on a novel breakthrough that marks a significant departure from current capabilities.

Q_given_P.title: Given a biotechnology breakthrough leads to a significant increase in global GDP by 2030, will the United States lead the world in quantum computing technology development by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a biotechnology breakthrough is directly linked to a significant increase in global GDP. A "significant increase" is defined as a rise in global GDP by at least 5% over a baseline year, adjusted for inflation, attributable to biotechnological advancements. In the event of multiple contributing factors to GDP growth, the biotechnology breakthrough must be identified as the primary driver. This question does not consider incremental improvements in existing biotechnologies but focuses on a novel breakthrough that marks a significant departure from current capabilities.

If the above condition is met, will the United States be recognized as the global leader in the development of quantum computing technology by December 31, 2030? Leadership will be determined based on the following criteria:

- Number of quantum computers developed that surpass the capabilities of existing classical computers in significant computational tasks (quantum supremacy).
- Volume and impact of peer-reviewed scientific publications originating from the United States that contribute to quantum computing technology.
- Investment in quantum computing research and development by both the public and private sectors in the United States, compared to other countries.

Global leadership must be recognized by at least two of the following authoritative sources: the International Quantum Computing Association, the IEEE Quantum Computing Task Force, or significant coverage in at least three major technology or science news outlets (e.g., Wired, MIT Technology Review, Nature).

In the event of a dispute over leadership, the consensus among these sources will be considered definitive.

P.title: Will a significant discovery in space lead to a new economic model or job sector as predicted by the Bureau of Labor Statistics by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant discovery in space leads to the creation of a new economic model or job sector, as predicted or recognized by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). A "significant discovery in space" refers to any discovery beyond Earth's atmosphere that has a direct and substantial impact on economic models, job creation, or the restructuring of existing job sectors. The new economic model or job sector must be officially acknowledged by the BLS in their publications or on their official website. In the absence of direct acknowledgment from the BLS, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the economic impact of the discovery will suffice. The discovery must lead to the creation of jobs that did not exist prior to the discovery, and these jobs must be recognized as part of a new sector or economic model. Temporary or speculative job creation does not meet this criterion. The question resolves as Yes only if the new economic model or job sector is operational and recognized by the end of 2030.

Q_given_P.title: Given a significant discovery in space leads to a new economic model or job sector by 2030, will the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines lead to a permanent change in workplace dynamics by 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: By December 31, 2030, a significant discovery in space leads to the creation of a new economic model or job sector, as predicted or recognized by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). A "significant discovery in space" refers to any discovery beyond Earth's atmosphere that has a direct and substantial impact on economic models, job creation, or the restructuring of existing job sectors. Temporary or speculative job creation does not meet this criterion. The question resolves as Yes only if the new economic model or job sector is operational and recognized by the end of 2030.

Then, will the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines lead to a permanent change in workplace dynamics by 2030? This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is a significant and permanent change in workplace dynamics directly attributable to the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines. Significant change is defined as:
- A permanent increase of at least 20% in the number of employees working remotely or in hybrid models compared to pre-pandemic levels (2019).
- The implementation of permanent flexible working hours by at least 50% of Fortune 500 companies.
- The establishment of permanent health and safety protocols in the workplace, including but not limited to vaccination requirements, that were not standard prior to the pandemic.

Changes must be documented by credible sources, including but not limited to surveys by major human resources consultancies (e.g., Deloitte, PwC), reports from reputable news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian), or official statements from companies. Temporary measures or changes solely due to government mandates that are lifted do not count towards this question's resolution.

Then, will a significant international climate change treaty be ratified by 2030? A "significant" treaty is defined as one that includes commitments from at least 75% of the world's nations and aims to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% from 1990 levels by 2050. The treaty must be ratified by the participating countries' governments or relevant governing bodies. Ratification is confirmed through official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The treaty must be new, not an amendment or extension of an existing treaty. In the event of multiple treaties, the question resolves as Yes if at least one meets these criteria.

In the absence of direct acknowledgment from the BLS, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the economic impact of the discovery will suffice. The discovery must lead to the creation of jobs that did not exist prior to the discovery, and these jobs must be recognized as part of a new sector or economic model. Temporary or speculative job creation does not meet this criterion. The question resolves as Yes only if the new economic model or job sector is operational and recognized by the end of 2030.

(b) There is a significant and permanent change in workplace dynamics directly attributable to the widespread adoption of COVID-19 vaccines. Significant change is defined as:
- A permanent increase of at least 20% in the number of employees working remotely or in hybrid models compared to pre-pandemic levels (2019).
- The implementation of permanent flexible working hours by at least 50% of Fortune 500 companies.
- The establishment of permanent health and safety protocols in the workplace, including but not limited to vaccination requirements, that were not standard prior to the pandemic.

Changes must be documented by credible sources, including but not limited to surveys by major human resources consultancies (e.g., Deloitte, PwC), reports from reputable news organizations (BBC, The New York Times, The Guardian), or official statements from companies. Temporary measures or changes solely due to government mandates that are lifted do not count towards this question's resolution.

(c) A significant international climate change treaty is ratified. A "significant" treaty is defined as one that includes commitments from at least 75% of the world's nations and aims to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% from 1990 levels by 2050. The treaty must be ratified by the participating countries' governments or relevant governing bodies. Ratification is confirmed through official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The treaty must be new, not an amendment or extension of an existing treaty. In the event of multiple treaties, the question resolves as Yes if at least one meets these criteria.

P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major ethical controversy in medical research leads to the implementation of new global health care policies or significant amendments to existing ones. The new or amended policies must be aimed at addressing the ethical concerns raised and must be adopted by at least 50% of the member states of the World Health Organization.
